posts.cooked:
Confer Blog ‚Äì 23 Dec 25

Confessions to a data lake

I‚Äôve been building Confer: end-to-end encryption for AI chats. With Confer, your conversations are encrypted so that nobody else can see them. Confer can‚Äôt read them, train on them, or hand them over ‚Äì because only you have access to them.

link_counts.title: Confessions to a data lake | Confer Blog

posts.cooked: Unclear how is this supposed to work. Homomorphic encryption? How is the encryption key stored? Browser storage mechanism? Then the service can send malicious JavaScript to a specific user to obtain the encryption key or outright send chat contents to a server in plaintext.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i think there‚Äôs something more fundamental that‚Äôs an issue. just like with E2EE the message needs to get decrypted at some point so that the person can talk to you, a large language model can‚Äôt work with the random data that is encrypted text, meaning it has to be plaintext at the endpoint. and just like you shouldn‚Äôt chat with adversaries because the best encryption can‚Äôt save you from your chat partner, the best encryption of your LLM history can‚Äôt save you from the LLM saving your data while it‚Äôs unencrypted. sure, if they didn‚Äôt do it at some point that text is now lost to them and they can‚Äôt get it back, but as soon as you continue that conversation, since previous text is part of the context for the continuing conversation and as such part of the eventually-plaintext prompt, they could grab it then.
there‚Äôs ways to increase one‚Äôs trust in the bot that‚Äôs on the other side of the connection. a very clear privacy policy and the publishing of source code that you could reasonably believe is the source code actually running on the server is a great start.
but if the thing you don‚Äôt trust is the provider, there‚Äôs not much one can do. it‚Äôs like chatting with someone you think is actively trying to leak your messages - even if you set a disappearing message timer of 5 seconds, they may still have a screen recording going on the entire time.

QuickBanana:

How is the encryption key stored?

It shows me this:

image468√ó324 12.1 KB

But, unless it uses some form of homomorphic encryption, I don‚Äôt see a way to make it really private. E2EE or not, LLM needs plaintext to knowwhat people want from it.

DirkPitt1:

It shows me this:

Ok so it‚Äôs this Public Signal Backups Testing - #237 by QuickBanana . Still, malicious JavaScript could steal data anyway. Moxie bragged a lot about this when people asked for a web version of Signal and now this ‚Äúprivate LLM‚Äù somehow doesn‚Äôt have this limitation or doesn‚Äôt matter.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: I can‚Äôt seem to get bitwarden to save the key for confer

Is this something like Proton‚Äôs Lumo? This is lacking a lot of details about how it accomplishes the supposed E2EE. Even Lumo decrypts the message at the LLM and just does their best to not keep the plaintext around.

DirkPitt1:

But, unless it uses some form of homomorphic encryption, I don‚Äôt see a way to make it really private.

Yes, absolutely. And I don‚Äôt think it is, because I believe they‚Äôd have mentioned that. And if it were homomorphic encryption, it would probably be too slow for most people.

There are hardware or software features that could execute the code in a somehow protected environment. Like Intel SGX afaik.

But I dont think that this works well with the requirements of running an LLM on tensor cores (or at least a powerful GPU)
Apple has been doing something similar for a while now: Private Cloud Compute: A new frontier for AI privacy in the cloud - Apple Security Research

link_counts.title: Private Cloud Compute: A new frontier for AI privacy in the cloud - Apple Security Research

posts.cooked:
Confer Blog ‚Äì 5 Jan 26

Private inference

When you use an AI service, you‚Äôre handing over your thoughts in plaintext. The operator stores them, trains on them, and‚Äìinevitably‚Äìwill monetize them. You get a response; they get everything.

Are there any estimates yet as to how secure it is (also in comparison to SPX) and how much attack surface it offers? Could this be a really big opportunity? It could also be really cool to combine it with server control, like with Lumo from Proton.

Essentially it works like Apple Intelligence, but built on Google confidential computing platform. Not truly end-to-end as expected. Also doesn‚Äôt cover the issue of web server being hacked, but might be solved with a simple app.
